author: NC B.

description: This place is Solid, in terms that you get a Big Burrito, your quesadilla or your nachos, and it's what expected "a Huge Americano Hog Fest", which by no means is meant to sound as a derogatory statement in part of Taqueria Cancun. However, yes here is the However/ Comma part of the review, their food just doesn't have that magic SAZON (spice) that you crave when sinking your teeth into a giant mass of mexico wrapped into a flour tortilla. I'm still trying to figure it out, let me get back to you with an updated review as I keep comparing it to others around the neighborhood. I hope to uncover the missing ingredient for you.......hmmmm maybe it's the Lard/salt proportion that goes into the mix, who knows , like I said I'll get back to you on this hehehe.
author: Lannette G.

description:
Y'know after seeing all of those "Best Of" awards for Taqueria Cancun, I figured well jeeze I better check this place out, considering how much I love Mexican Food. 

Well after a visit to Cole Hardware I thought I'd peep the sitch. I wandered over to Taqueria Cancun and tried a burrito with asada. I was not impressed. The burrito was rather dry, they put waaay too much rice, and the salsas were not anything special.

I give this place 3 stars, because I'm nice. But hey, I hear the tacos are pretty good? So maybe I'll have to go back and return with an update.
author: Jena R.

description:
3.49 so I couldn't round up to 4 (sorry)

Live here almost a year and my first mission burrito.  To be fair I don't like Mexican food (I know -- stop reading now and skip to the next review) but I was *really* hungry and wanted something fast and cheap, what are my choices in the mission?

Back to the Burrito, Super (chicken)  no beans or rice - it was good.  Great flavor, salsa, sour cream, avocado and the perfect amount of kick (heat).  Great value, place was fine, good service no complaints.
author: Jas S.

description: Great big burritos, a little to spicy for me but that's just how the Mexican salsa is I guess.  Will be heading back again soon.  If you're in town for a short amount of time this is one of the place you have to eat at!
author: Eric G.

description: A good neighborhood taqueria.  The burritos are better than average, but I go for the gluten-free tacos, which tend to have the filling break through soggy soft taco shells.  If you are looking for a good, quick meal, this is the place.  The hours are accommodating, too.
author: Sean R.

description: Get the Burrito Mojado.  It's awesome.  Don't forget to bring cash, they don't take cards!
author: Travis S.

description:
Came here and I asked for pozole, in which I was looked upon like I asked for something that is never served. So I continued to order a Super Chicken Burrito. I wanted a Strawberry fresca, but they only had Horchata & Cantelope,which I don't really like. I waited like 5mins for food which is great. The place seemed clean (minus the cockroach on the floor) lil buddy probably wanted some food (HAHA). Overall it was a mediocre experience I'm starting to think all these damn taquerias aren't as good as I thought. Seems like bigger prices for not so great food and are catering to things like Veggie, which is great but hey don't forget about the authentic food.

Quick Tip: Cash Only
author: Sarina I.

description:
The food is edible and good if you live close by or just getting out of el rio, knockout, etc.

I was unimpressed with their quesadilla.  It was on the small size and didn't nearly have the taste of el faro, but it did the trick in a lazy pinch.  Sarina, that same roach was in line too, but sadly, that was the last time he is going to order because someone put the smack down to lil roachee.

My friends liked the burritos which I didn't have an opportunity to try, but maybe next time.
author: Po L.

description: Came here this past Sunday night. Ordered the super prawns burrito as I usually do. What I didn't know was that it also came with a bad case of the stomach flu. Never coming here again.  Beware when ordering seafood here. Save yourself the agony.
author: Cynthia Z.

description:
This is hands down the best burrito in the city!

I am picky as hell when it comes to my Mexican food~ and this place is exactly what I want.  I *love* that they put actual avocado into my burrito- I don't really want guacamole~ I want avocado and it is like someone finally read my mind.

And the secondary factors... the chips are yummy, the people are nice, and the place is bright and cheerful!  I love how close it is to my fave dive bar and would never go to one without the other~
author: Amy M.

description:
The chorizo tacos at Taqueria Cancun are hands down the best tacos I had in SF and possibly anywhere else.  I actually lost track of the number of times I went here during my brief one week stay.  

Words cannot describe the delight that awaits you when you order a chorizo taco.  I won't even try. Just go here.
author: Christopher R.

description:
So in Sweden, tacos and burritos is not the most common food.
The tacos that we do have taste like plastic bag and tomato with some tasteless green "suppose to be guacamole" sauce, all I can say is that it taste like authentic Swedish shit.

So of course I had to order a vegetarian burrito at Cancun.
I have to be honest with you, I was expecting more.
My disappointment might have to do with the fact that I had no cheese, sour cream or salsa in my burrito, so I had some brown rice with very little avocado however I did take a bite from my friends burrito and that one was so much better.

I will have another try, maybe at the other spot.
All and all it was a OK place, the bread could have been a bit more toasted and I was disappointed that they missed my salsa.
author: cecilia k.

description: Seriously the best taquria in the city.  It gets four stars instead of 5 because I ordered a super taco and got a super burrito instead (which is what I was charged for).  I wasn't that hungry but still ate half the burrito.  And was sad the rest of the entire night for wasting the other half because it was so good.  Fresh ingredients and solid food.  Can't go wrong.
author: Jessica C.

description: The best burritos, deliciously overstuffed, for a great price. There's a reason the wall is covered in awards.
author: Surat L.

description:
just stumbled in on a late Wednesday night, happy anything was open, scanned the menu with my friend Alexx, turned to him and decisively said, "how bout we get the super nachos to split."  With meat?  yeah, with chorizo!  I know this seems like a bad idea at first, a misstep on an otherwise pleasant, lightly intoxicated Wednesday, but it just seemed like the right idea at the time.  One of those instances where at least 85% percent of the time its the wrong idea, but this time, well just this time it worked out; like instead of, "oh that night was just going swimmingly until we ordered fricking chorizo on the super nachos."

What's great about super nachos is that it takes like all the supporting characters from Mexican food  and makes a fairly solid stand alone meal out of it.  Like typically if you tried this in any other genre of food, it would fail miserably; like oh, I'll take hamburger meat, pickles, onions and tomato and put on a tray, bake it, slap some ketchup....you get the idea, like a clown in the kitchen basically.  And yeah, nachos are kind of like low-brow bachelor food, but that's only if you make it at home in your microwave, where as when you order it from a taqueria/restaurant it takes on a much classier appeal.  The kind of classy that only a taqueria on mission street that's open until 3am can provide.

A few caveats about ordering the super nachos with chorizo after midnight on a weekday (a weekend you have plenty of time to recover).  One:  Ask for the sour cream on the side.  Don't get overconfident.  You know that sour cream can do damage at that hour, but what is worst, is that when they smother the nachos in it, it not only turns a layered platter of beauty into a soggy, sloppy mess, it always (at least for me) makes me kind of feel depressed after eating them.  I can't really explain why (in this forum), but it has something to do with regret, gluttony, and disillusionment.

The second caveat is:  don't be foolish and try eating this by yourself (again with the overconfidence), or don't try splitting it with someone who pecks at food like a bird or who's too interested in talking about themselves and loses sight of what is most immediate and important, which is tearing through some kick-ass super nachos.......I mean c'mon people, you gotta live!  You could split this three ways and it would still carry its weight.   Godammit, I just made myself hungry.
author: James W.

description:
My roomies and I strolled down to Mission to play taqueria roulette and pick something we hadn't tried before. On the fence between a Salvadoran pupuseria  or tradtional Mexican fare, we walked past Can-Cun. I'd seen it walking thru the neighborhood, and admit I was adverse to the glaring yellow and bright lights. But after checking the menu and prices decided to give it a go. 

I tried the prawn burrito, my roomie had the veggie, and other dude had the carnitas burrito. The server brought them out after a short wait, and handed each to the wrong person. I bit into the carnitas and was like "wow" this is great. Veggie bit into my prawn, and my man bit into the veggie and exclaimed how good it was (and he is NOT a vegetarian). I knew mine was not prawn, but I was almost not going to hand it over it was so good. The seasoning was yum, if not a tad too salty, but calmed down by the sour cream (and the Mexican Coca-Cola). When we finally sorted it out, I enjoyed my prawn burrito, though I wished the seasoning on the shrimp was just a notch more like the carnitas. I tasted my pal's veggie burrito and it was quite hearty and tasty.  All of our burritos had been toasted on the grill before and serving, so they had a nice hot toasty taste.

While I am sure there are equal or better places in the area, this was good inexpensive and fresh tasting. 

Chips are salty and clearly not home made. I think my favorite chips in the city are from Maya downtown on 2nd near Harrison.
author: Jon L.

description:
I get the veggie burritto w/enchilada sauce inside. Messy and mouth-watering, aye mami!

And it's right by the Knockout, hollah!
author: Faith S.

description: the tacos are massive and the burriotos are great! The meat has flavor which is what makes or breaks a good Mexican joint ;)
author: Glenda R.

description:
Best burrito in the city.  There's a reason they keep winning the Best in the Bay award.  

I'm not one to exaggerate but I'd step over my own mother for their El Pastor Super Nachos.  The super burritos are excellent, using big thick slices of real avocado.  One last note, the green sauce they serve with the free chips will change your life.  Colors will be brighter, birds will sing to you and rainbows will appear at random.  Damn I love acid.  

Bring cash because they don't do the card thing (Welcome to the Mission) and enjoy the comical, late-night hipster contingent  while waiting for your food.  You're always bound to hear a conversation laced with grand opinions and self-referential pomposity.
author: Yoni M.

description:
Just like Cancun down at Mission and 19th except minus the drunk hipster overflow from neighboring inner mission bars. Which is good. Because I like to get my burrito on in as zen a fashion as possible. 

Downside? If taqueria fare makes you gassy, you'll need to leg it out of there straight away. It's so quiet in here, everyone will know it was you.
author: Autumn K.

description: BEST SUPER BURRITO de Al Pastor by far. For the longest La Tapatia in South City was my go to place for a burrito. I was always let down by other places but one late night feening for a burrito I was brought into Taqueria Cancun and of course I went with the AL Pastor because honestly it's the best kind of meat that is just meant to be in a Super Burrito. The pork is marinated so well and with hints of pineapple take this burrito over the top. Be sure to ask for extra green salsa, pour that over each bite of the burrito, foodgasm each time. Most places charge $10+ for a super burrito, here at Cancun the prices are fair and cheaper than most places. Don't forget to grab an Agua Fresca, usually they have 2 flavors, Horchata and Melon. Both are amazing. Service is fast here. I order over the phone and most times they say "okay ready in 5 mins." Quickest service I've received other than a fast food place. Definitely my #1 go to place for a super burrito.
author: Liza E.

description: I thank Jesus at least three times a week that these guys are open past 1am!
author: O. S.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite taquerias. The griddled tortilla and the chunks of avocado as opposed to guacamole really make the difference. The horchata is pretty delicious as well.

I do have a couple of minor complaints though. 

The chips are almost always stale. C'mon guys, invest in a couple of twist ties.

No carnitas. No CARNITAS?

Don't get the chorizo unless you're surrounded by people who love you. I mean REALLY love you. This may be the true test of loyalty. I'll say no more than that.

Oh, and one more thing. DO NOT EAT ONE OF THESE BURRITOS BEFORE GOING TO WORK (like I did yesterday.) Your co-workers WILL find you lying unconscious in a corner from a meat induced coma.
author: Josua P.

description:
Post-drinking taqueria-munchies must be some kind of SF rite of passage.  You people who grew up here, you have no idea what shit we had to eat in the Midwest after a night of imbibing - with the exception of the Pork Burger Man at my college (bless that man!), it was slim pickings.  Doritos and Hostess donuts, or Taco Bell - ugggghhhh....Taquerias are the diners of the West Coast - they serve both the young and old, they are open all the time, and when you gotta have it, you gotta have it.  You know what I mean.

Everything on the menu is what you would expect, but I am going to tell you something VERY useful, here is the best item they offer:  1 Taco.

1 Taco.  It couldn't be more simple.  Or more delicious.

Get it with the carnitas (they must not have had them before, but they do now).  So savory and wonderful.  SO much better than the burrito and won't make you pop your pants' button.

It's so good that it almost makes the electric urine colored walls, the drunk teenagers talking on the phone, and the "is it a guy or is it a girl" people disappear.

Road map:  Argus.  Stool dancing.  Taqueria Cancun. 1 Taco.  Car dancing.  Home.  Bed.
author: Liz S.

description: I always love Cancun. I didn't realize there was one this far down though. It was a pleasant surprise to say the least. I can't resist a breakfast burrito anytime of day, especially after consuming a lot of drinks. Service is good, lots of space and conveniently located near a bunch of bars too :)
author: Greg G.

description:
Not as good as I remember. I guess when you're 22 and broke this stuff tastes great! 

We came here before we headed over to the Rocket Dog Rescue benefit at El Rio. (BTW, I won one of those Kristina R. "Not Normal Yes Normal" t-shirts in the raffle!) 

Had a veggie burrito and husband had a torta. Food tasted ok. Salsa was HOT. Self serve jalapenos were HOT. Food inspection score card displaying 66%...not so HOT.
author: Caroline C.

description:
2.5 stars, actually.

Taqueria Cancun is a prime example of what hype can do. Just check out the overall Yelp ratings of all 3 of their outposts:

1) 19th & Mission: At the Hipster epicenter of Mission: 4 stars
2) This location: At the outskirts of Hipville: 3.5 stars
3) 6th & Market: At crack cocaine central: 3 stars

So due to liquor induced hunger, I now have been to all three of these locations. Taking hype (lack thereof) out of the equation, there's no drastic difference in food quality, overall, it's barely reaching "all right." But, this location is waaay less crowded, and no scooby-doo extras (see my other TC review http://www.yelp.com/user_details_reviews_self?userid=e331pQV1I-SSnWw_w0PfMA&review_sort=time&review_filter=category&category_filter=mexican) in sight.

So if I limit my crappy chips intake, and fireball "guacamole" salsa intake, not get the carne asada, chorizo, beef quesadilla suiza or nachos from this place, I can actually walk out and think that this place is a-okay.

So what did I have here that was actually good? Quesadilla Suiza with Al Pastor and their Horchata.
author: Faffy L.

description: Ever since I found this place, I've been getting the Burrito Mojado ever since. Such a good burrito! Also the salsa and guac is perfect while waiting for the MOJADO!!!!
author: Danny P.

description:
I like how they hyphenate Can-cun. I like all the options on the menu. I like the idea of super tacos; they're tough to eat as tacos, but the size is such that one makes for a light meal and two is a full dinner, and that they don't induce food comas the way super burritos do. And I like the tacos al pastor here a lot. 

Not really digging the red and yellow color scheme though.
author: matthew r.

description:
$4.50 al pastor burrito?

Check.

Enough food to make me feel like I'm gonna yack?

Check.

Meat choices that include beef head, tongue and brains?

Check.

I thought it was great, and I was only slightly buzzed.  The place smelled bad (as others point out), so do take out.  I'll give an update once this bad boy works its way through my system on my ski trip tomorrow.

Or is that TMI?
author: Rocco B.

description: I like the vegetarian burrito and nachos, with no sour cream.  This location seems quieter than the others, so that works for me too.
author: Seong P.

description:
Last night I had an interesting combination of Thai and Mexican.  I know .... but it went well.

I ordered a Quesidilla Suiza with al pastor, and it was greasy and good.  But I forgot to add onions, which I will next time.  The pork has lots of flavor, but I wanted more heat.  Next I will try the burritos and / or alambres.  

My only gripe is the lack of salsa provided with the chips, which are complimentary.  I got a tablespoon or so of salsa.  I wanted to dunk everything in it, but I got so little that after a couple of chips, it was gone.  I also found a piece of carne asada in the salsa, which might be expected, but was slightly disturbing.  

I think I'll go back, but will ask for more salsa on the side.  One quesidilla does NOT a review make!
author: Michael M.

description:
This place sucks.

The salsa sucks.  The rice sucks.  The chips suck.

Only vegetarians like this place because apparently they put a ton of veggies in the veggie burrito, but even if that did appeal to me (which it most definitely does not) then it wouldn't hide the fact that it's still a shitty burrito with funky-tasting rice and awful salsa.

I can't understand how this place wins so many "readers' choice" awards because it just flat out fucking sucks.
author: Doctor L.

description:
Taqueria Cancun is pretty much my neighbor. This comes in very handy on the rare occasion that I am drunk and craving a  late-night quesadilla. The quesadillas rock, but everything else is just okay. I have come to love El Metate and totally prefer it over Cancun. 

There's just no way they have the best burrito in the city. Not a chance.
author: Abby W.

description: Really greasy and not particularly good. I just think the quality at La Taqueria (a few blocks down the road) is much much better. Not terrible but not even really ok. It certainly passes a health code inspection but might cause an upset stomach from all of the grease. Only recommend if you are drunk and need it ASAP and nothing else is open.
author: Ben L.

description:
Just checked out their vegetarian burritos, heard their names in the foodies news everywhere so I said to myself I cannot miss it...
Indeed, their food is good and the ambiance quite genuine. However, and sorry all the hard fans, I do take Chipotle's vegetarian burrito over this one.
First, they do have the bowl which avoids you  the wrap; second, they are so simple and good, it is just like a good salad with a beans base...
Anyways, there cannot be dispute when it comes to tastes, as Latins said, they are all good, depends on what you like better...
author: VIORICA C.

description: This is my burrito and nachos standard in the city. Carne Asada burrito comes heavy on toppings and lots of meat. Usually get it to go, and eat it at home. Hard to beat their flavorful burritos and spicy salsa.
author: Darren K.

description:
Ok, i give you a second chance Cancun. Your just Meh, but maybe that is all I need sometimes.

ps. your rice sucks.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Taqueria Cancun saved my relationship last night!  No really, it did.

I was in a crappy mood.  I wanted to go to Whole Foods, but everyone and their brother were headed to the ballpark to see Barry.  I tried to buy groceries at Bi-Rite and it seems that all the non-ballpark goers were there. So, with my crap attitude I went home.  I wasn't up for my usual of GFC...and it dawned on me to go and have a cheap dinner and get out of the house.

I walked over to Taqueria Cancun and then realized how much cleaner this location is to the others.  How nice it is to not have the music blaring.  And an extra plus, no homeless people asking you for leftovers. 

I ordered a burrito mojado with carne asada and for $5.90 it seemed to have changed my attitude. Not only was it fast and delicious, but the price was right. 

Yes, I came home with a better attitude and a great dinner all for under $6.  Could you ask for anything better?
author: Valarie A.

description:
Ive been to this Taqueria Cancun a handful of times and its about average.  Their burritos are good but not great, they make a pretty good horchata and their prices are cheap. 

I went last night with a friend who is always raving about their al pastor burritos so I decided to try one.  To me it was just ok, the burrito overall was fine, wasnt too dry but the al pastor was average.  I felt that it was TOO marinated, the flavor of the meet was too strong that it drowned out the rest of the ingredients.

Other comments; they only use avocado and no guacamole, which is fine but I prefer guacamole. They do happen to have a really good horchata probably the 2nd best int he city behind the El Farolito in the Excelsior.  Their prices are also very low, the average taqueria in the city charges $7-10 for a super burrito.

All in all, this place was just ok. If I am with a group of people and they want to go here Ill go but if its my choice, Ill go to El Farolito.
author: Ian P.

description: Always good food here. My favorite burritos. Burritos - try the carnitas, veggie and carne asada ... I tried the tostadas de ceviche today, liked those too. Try the pickled jalapenos in the big tub by the water dispenser.
author: Dana G.

description:
I second all these emotions...they make the best burrito in SF. I highly recommend the carnitas-YUM YUM! The lighting is a bit like a hospital waiting room but that just makes it easier to see the hombres caliente that work there. 

Don't miss out on a truly delicious and satisfying burrito.
author: Nick B.

description:
Forget any other mexican joint in the mission. Here's why: you know you're at a great taqueria if the only types of salsa are HOT and "where's the flippin' water?" HOT. None of that v8 broth that other taquerias pass off as salsa

Get the horchata (you'll need it for salsa). Do yourself a favor and order the super quesadilla. It's the size of a burrito. Cancun doesn't mess around. They remove the rice and beans filler that comes in a burrito and they fill it with sour cream, huge slices of avocado, meat, and cheese. Too much good stuff. I have brought over thirty friends here, and everyone of them has told me that it was the best quesadilla they've ever had in their lives. No joke.

Don't waste your time with similiar resturants in the mission, I promise (and I've evaluated them), they don't compare. Okay they come close, because who really cares when you're wasted? Nevertheless, Cancun is open till 2am on weeknights, 3am on weekends, so it's there when you really need it (eg: when you're drunk).
author: John M.

description:
Ok there are 3 cancuns that I visit frequently, but this one still                   "takes the cake".

This is the 1st taqueira cancun I have ever visited. the 2 others                         ( mission and 18th) and (Market and 6th( are defintiely worth mentioning but like I said this is the best one.

This one I think has the most clean seating. The employees are more generally nicer and engaging. There juke-box IMO has the best selection too, lol.

The parking at dinner time sux but I cant blame that on this rest.

I'm at a lost for words on how fantastic this specific rest. is
It will always be my #1 taqueria in all of San Francisco.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Time was, I had this to say about Cancun ,"It's open late and is better than Farolito. But it has more friends than it deserves. Mediocre, says me.".

Man was I sassy? Turns out, I was thinking about the Cancun near 19th. The one up in Bernal on Market (this one) is way better. It's not *great*, but it's satisfying and flavorful and cheap and I don't constantly have to hear about it from cheapskate, drunk at a Mission-bar types who think it's the end-all. As with the original Cancun.

The salsa verde is actually too goddamn hot. See if you don't agree. And man, are the chips ever crummy. But otherwise OK.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
To start off, I would like to disclose that I have a rule to only leave reviews after patronizing a business at least 5 times so my reviews aren't made willy-nilly. 

Best tacos I've found so far in SF. 

Trick - get one super taco and one regular taco, as they usually put so much "super" on the taco, that it can be shared with a regular taco.  Or, if you're feeling naughty, just get two super tacos.   Quesadillas are pretty tasty too.  I don't think I've had a burrito from here...I come here for tacos, and other joints for burritos.
author: L W.

description: I love this place. Affordable, friendly service and the portions are big. I ordered the steak enchiladas for around $7 and was presented with an enormous plate (2 enchiladas, a mountain of rice, beans, sour cream etc.) plus four hot tortillas. And they don't skimp on the complimentary chips and salsa (2 kinds). Definitely coming back.
author: Kareem Y.

description:
Eh. Perhaps it was the measly taco, but my last experience at Cancun was pretty unmemorable. And no, I wasn't drunk! Well, I wasn't THAT drunk, anyway. The Mission location serves up a badass veggie burrito, but the taco I got here was pretty blah. I do, however, love the slices of avocado used in lieu of guacamole because they add this buttery richness that is sometimes lost in guac. Occasionally I'm into simplicity over complexity, and no, it's not cuz I'm stupid. I have my Master's, for christ's sake! The amount of money I've spent on my education OBVIOUSLY points to my immense and intimidating intelligence, right? Right? Someone, please validate my choice to spend the rest of my life in debt! Throw me a bone, people! Or at least a dollar!

Anyway, Cancun's cheap, meaning that I can actually afford to eat here, and the salsa does meet my required level of spiciness. I would prefer an actual salsa bar, but the chips are so crappy that it doesn't matter that much.  Also, if you're looking for vegetarian nachos that will inevitably cause a heart attack, skip Cancun and make your way over to Farolito, trust me. Remember, I have my MA so I'm totally a credible source. Okay, someone needs to positively reinforce me RIGHT THE FUCK NOW. 

You know, I should probably just stick to the burrito. Tastes better, which serves as good reason to eat more than a stupid taco, and I deem any reason to eat more as successful.
author: Chloe S.

description:
Best veggie burrito in the city.  Hands down.  I love the way they grill the burrito till the tortilla is lightly crispy.  Not to mention, even with the price increase they are one of the cheapest burritos in town.

Oh and the salsa verde is quite tasty with just enough heat.

Huge love for Cancun!
author: Trey d.

description:
When I'm bar-hopping in the Mission, I hit up the Cancun on 19th and Mission, but when I'm hoping to find parking, I go to the Bernal Heights location. Either way, I know I will leave full and happy. 

Since moving to Oakland, I've had frequent cravings for Cancun's vegetarian burrito. Soooo tasty. I love the melty cheese, the guac, the whole beans...it's just too good. 

Any East-Bayers wanna get together a Cancun Carpool, let me know!!
author: Vandana M.

description:
Burritos in this town is like religion. Everyone has an opinion and as soon as you open your mouth about yours, people either yawn in retort or want to ram their fist in it, so be careful what you say. The thing is, unless you get one of them new fangled California burritos with olives and arugula (lord have mercy on your soul) they really aren't that different other than 1) the care of the assembly 2) the relative freshness of the ingredients (look at how brown the lettuce is for any indication) and of course 3) the general safety of eating there (check out their health department certificate and police blotter). That said, I will stand firmly by the Burnal Cancun.

I have no idea what level of affiliation this location has with it's other namesakes, but there is no question that this is the best of the lot based on the above standards. Always go for the *grilled* chicken, and grab your own personal bottle of Cholula to smother every bite. I think what distinguishes this place from other burrito chutes in town is that the contents are not only fresh, but evenly distributed throughout the burrito and made with a consistent ratio. There is always plenty of room to sit, and the water glasses are almost always clean.
author: Matt L.

description:
For a taqueira, TC is one of the best in the city I think. Although you get less for atmosphere and dining conditions than some places, the quality of the food and the prices are actually very good. Generally, if you ask for  a veggie burrito at TC, you get a humongous thing barely capable of consumption at one sitting. If you add in a little meat, it's definitely a complete meal. Also their chips are some of the better chips-to-go-with as I have had at SF taquerias. I also like the agua frescas, esp. the watermelon one.
If they could only conquer a small fly problem, they would be heads over heels above Pancho Villa's or some of the other Mission district places.
author: Mark L.

description:
Simply the best burrito in the city.  I've lived here over 15 years now and I've tried just about every taqueria in the mission (no small feat), but this is the place that keeps me coming back.  I don't think there has been a month in the last 15 years that I haven't eaten here at least once. 

The meats are grilled fresh imediately before going into the tortilla, the rice and beans are nicely seasoned and would be a treat by themselves.  Avocado is a nice addition to anything and their salsas are the best I've ever had.  They even sell salsa by the cup so you can take it home or to your friend's party.  Your guests won't leave you any left over when the party's over - it's just that good. 

I didn't even mention the price yet. How can this food be so good and still so inexpensive? I don't know why, I'm just glad it is.

Taqueria Cancun is worth the trip from anywhere in the bay area.
author: Bryce M.

description:
I don't understand why this place got so many Zagat reviews...

Even though it offers a good portion for an inexpensive price...their super burrito being roughly $5..which is good if you are broke and want your $5 to go a long way. ...but i still wouldn't pay for it. 

I've gave this place two shots, and I dont' think I will be visiting back, unless I absolutely have no where to eat at 12am.

The last time I got a super burrito= meat had way too much fat and the guacamole was all brown.

To top it off, I got to enjoy my food with the bleach scent filling up the restaurant.
author: Catherine O.

description:
So, I have a story about this place ("Hey, Devin, do you have  a story about *every* place you review?" Maybe yes. Maybe no. Maybe fuck yourself.). 

There I was at the Knockout around 1:20a on some lovely weeknight, when BOOM it hit me: must. eat. now. Starvingstarving. No, stop talking interesting person, no I don't want a beer no I don't want to dance nonononononono we're leaving NOW musthaveburrito. This, um, happens to me a lot. Anyway, so I've just moved to the neighborhood, and am not yet terribly familiar with the local late night eats, so I had nothing in mind when we ventured out, leaving one darkness for another. Immediate right: oh god. Taqueria RIGHT THERE! Magnetized, I stumbled in, dumbstruck with our good luck. Order order, veggie burrito, no cheese, no sour cream, are your beans vegetarian, etc etc. Sit down, across the table from my date (that was a date, right mister?), they call my number, I do some kind of embarrassing standing/falling motion that gets the burrito in my hands and onto the table which I once again find in front of me. Bite: ohgodamazing. Bite: ohholyshitbestthingever. Several bites later:

Drop.

Wha?Wh-y?Wha---why is it down...what is? Why...whys my burrito on the floor? Neither one of us could figure out how I had managed to drop my burrito on the floor--face down, my I add. And now, here it comes: the testament to how great this burrito was. Within moments, before we could even begin to truly debate it, the thing was back in my mouth. I was back to making out with that same juicy-beany-guacy-pico-y surface that had been smooshed down onto the taqueria floor.

This was like, my....third? date with a guy I really liked. And I let him watch me do that. I love Taqueria Cancun.
author: Devin F.

description:
Cancun (on Mission and Valencia, yes they cross) reliably serves the best vegetarian burrito in San Francisco.  I've been coming there since 1997, and the only thing that changed are the prices (used to be $2.65 for a veggie burrito).

Here's the perfect recipe: Vegetarian burrito with pinto beans, extra cilantro, extra avocado, and no sour cream.
author: A S.

description:
So around my house, there are two burrito places I frequent.  This place and El Gran Taco Loco (http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-gran-taco-loco-san-francisco).  Taco Loco is literally right across the street from my house (I often look out my window to make sure they're still open).

But recently, I find myself coming here more often, which if you know me, walking an extra block to get a burrito is quite a statement.  I think it's because of the "Best Burrito Ev4r!" awards they proudly display, or some combination of the fast service and cheap prices.  I really don't know why, because their burritos don't taste all that special.  Anyways, nothing really special, but not bad either; right down the middle.  I guess that makes it my little Buddhist burrito shop (blasphemous, I know).

Oh, they're open late too, so that's a big plus.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
I actually got burrito-jacked at this joint once.  No shit.  I was sitting there minding my own business, halfway through an al pastor or something, when I decided to walk across the room and get a cup of water.  In the 30 seconds or so it took me to do this, some guy just walked in off the street, picked up my half-eaten burrito, and started to walk out the door with it.

"Hey!  That's my burrito!", I yelled at him when I turned around from the water cooler.  He just kept going.

"HEY!  THAT'S MY FUCKING BURRITO!!!", I screamed, as all eyes in the room turned towards me.  The thief paused by the door for a second, took a quick glance over his shoulder, and set the burrito down on the nearest table, right in front of some other lucky patron who was finishing up his own order, and then just bolted.  

This one girl just laughed and laughed and laughed, like it was the funniest thing she'd ever seen.  "You just got burrito-jacked!", she said, barely able to keep her shit together through the hysterics.  Indeed I had.

The guy behind the counter witnessed the entire episode, and offered to make me another burrito.  I turned it down though.  I really wasn't that hungry to begin with, and I probably would've given the burrito thief the rest of my food if he'd just asked me.  That rip-and-run thing got my dander up, I guess.  

I left after that and went next door to watch Astral play some shoegaze rock at the Knockout.  

True story.
author: Gopal R.

description: So I came here looking to get the bad taste out of my mouth from the last burrito I had at El Toro. Thankfully, this did the trick. I was happy that the rice was moist, the pinto beans flavorful, and the carne asada smoky and delicious. My only gripe was the green salsa given with the chips was spicy but not very tasty. Also, the burrito leaked thru my brown paper bag, but that's SFs fault for banning plastic. At $5 for a reg burrito, I'll def return. My current fav burrito spot in SF.
author: Chantly S.

description:
Solely for the vegetarian burritos!!!

You will not miss the meat in these burritos. Very simple yet very very good. Once again don't skimp and get it with everything and a large melon drink. That's all that needs to be said. I once got the burrito with meat and didn't think much of it as much as the vegetarian. 

By the way the best meat taco is down the street on 25th and Mission, my other review La Taqueria.

AB
author: Anthony B.

description:
Boo!
Taqueria Cancun is not so great and I really don't get the hype particularly when there are SO many great Taquerias in the neighborhood.
Everything I have ever gotten here has been "meh" bland, boring etc.
Dude just walk down to El Faralito if you want a cheap and decent Taqueria experience. I'd even go to El Taco Loco (which is similarly "meh" aside from it's fabulous mural of a taco wearing sunglasses, really the only reason to go there) over this place.
Everytime I have mediocre mexican food in SF I get irritable:(
author: Catty C.

description:
This is the nearest burrito place from my front door, and it's a pretty good taqueria at that.  Their veggie burrito is excellent (hope you like lots of avocado) and their al pastor is tasty.  No carnitas, but their carne asada is good.  They usually have tasty cantoloupe agua fresca.  I would say they're probably just as good as El Farolito.

The patented Cancun decor consists of insane BRIGHT YELLOW walls covered with weird paintings of bare-chested Aztek warriors striking action poses while cavorting with beautiful latina maidens, and lots of colorful streamers hanging from the ceiling.
author: David A.

description:
This is my favorite burrito in all of SF.  I get the pollo asado regular with a spinach tortilla, and it is consistently fresh tasting and very, very delicious.  Inexpensive, and an easy, filling meal.

I have only two small criticisms: the chips are always stale and don't taste very good, and that sometimes, the juke-box springs on blaring unbelievably loudly after complete silence for ten minutes (on or off, guys!)
author: Brent D.

description: Yummy burrito, good tacos, and a great super quesadilla. One of my faves.
author: Zak S.

description:
I LOOOOVE CANCUN!!!! The Quesadillas and the melon Agua Fresca is my favorite. 
BEST IN THE MISSION
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I just got out of a pretty serious relationship with a carne asada super quesadilla from Cancun and let me tell you something, I have never been with a more giving, caring, nurturing lover than that quesadilla.  On the coldest of nights and the darkest of days that quesadilla smothered my worries in hot melted cheese and illuminated my spirit with it's bright south of the border flavors.

You simply cant ask for much more.  If only, I didn't get all caught up in those fish tacos from Nicks.  It was one time, I was drunk. I thought it didnt count if you were drunk...
author: zach o.

description:
Smell: Scary awful!

Food: Great!

My first visit to this Cancun location tonight.  The veggie Super Burrito was awesome.  But the place smelled like ASS.  I mean, it seriously smelled like somewhere there's a layer of something that has not been scraped off or degreased for a very long time.  It was empty in there.  Several people walked in, smelled the air and walked back out while I was eating.  I halfway didn't mind because the burrito was so good.  What can I say, I'm a hopeless burrito addict.

Update, months later: Yep, still smells like *ass* in there.  Yep, veggie super burrito still is *excellent*.  Go figure.  I really love the generous amount of cilantro.
author: Eric O.

description: My favorite burrito in the Bay Area.  Flavorful rice and beans, big chunks of avocado, a big filling portion.  The other offerings here are great too - the quesdilla suisa, the al hambre meat plate, etc.  The guys who work the register are usually friendly.  I lived a block from this place for twelve years, and often got a burrito there once a week.
author: Adam C.

description: Ok, I used to hate Cancun. I always thought their burritos were overrated. After refusing to enter Cancun for years, one afternoon we decided to try it out again. We ordered spicy super veg burritos, and when we took the first bite it, it was heaven. It had a ton of flavor. The salsas were great. I had to say, it managed to find its way into my top 5 veg burritos in the mission (It will stay there, if it remains consistent). Do not go to the one near 29th and mission, we went there a few days later and it was back to mediocre (will be posting there shortly as well).
author: Ajesh S.

description:
I used to eat at this Cancun location about 3 times a week, dinner, lunch, breakfasts.  I thought it was okay then - but it was my taqueria so I kept going back.  Lately I've been forced to eat burritos in other parts of town, and this has restored my faith in Cancun.

I had a veggie burrito here a while back, and dang, it was great.  Maybe I've been wandering the desert sub-par burritos too long, but I was impressed.  Mostly by the rice and beans, the rice was fluffy and bright bricky red with tasty zest and the beans were equally impressive.  As always great slabs of avocado and any cheese problems (there used to be some cheese problems) have now been solved.  They still grill the outside of your burrito better than any of their imitators and the green salsa is great (thought the red is abysmal).

Still, I also remember the times (well three that I can remember - though to be fair that's out of literally hundreds, if not thousands of visits over the past 5 years) that Cancun has made by belly churn, and I the more numerous times I've simply been bored with what I thought in my burrito arrogance was it's lackluster burrito.
author: Gustie L.

description:
With so many taqueria joints in the Mission, it would be hard to justify going back.  The carne asada was chopped too fine and close to ground beef.  Plus, they got creative with the al pastor, which is a dish that you aint got no bidnuh messin wit.  The salsa was HOT, and I loved it which is why this place gets two stars.  

"Go for the salsa, stay for the crackwhores outside."
author: Will H.

description: Only been here once but the chicken tacos with everything are awesome. My friend got the veggie taco and I wish I got that, but didn't regret the chicken. Chips, salsa and super-spicy guac with every order is a nice perk. I'll be back. VERY cheap! And beer! I checked that they have "beer and wine" on the additional tips, but I think they just serve beer.
author: S A.

description: I always get the super chicken quesadilla, this might be my favorite taqueria en the city.
author: Mark R.

description:
This is my favorite cheap and abso-freakin-lutely delicious burrito dive. I've been coming here since I was about 10 with my dad. And now I bring everybody here. 

The decor is a little tacky and overly colorful, but frankly, it's the best burrito in the city. Now, I haven't been all over the world tasting burritos, so I'm sure there's a better place SOMEWHERE out there. But I haven't found it yet. I am a die hard loyal Bernal Heights Taqueria Cancun fan. 

I don't order anything but burritos when I come here. And everybody I've ever taken has declared it either the best they've ever had, or bumps it right up near the top of their list.

YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED.
author: Mindy L.

description: I love Taqueria Cancun ! Okay, it helps that it's in my neighborhood but I would still seek out their veggie burrito with black beans, spinach tortilla and no sour cream ( my way) even if it was across town. I also love the enchilada plate, I'll order the grilled chicken enchiladas with whole beans on the side and extra avocado.  Mmm the enchilada sauce is delish !  To go or eat in it's service with a smile. As a friend in the neighborhood says, on a good day there's no better restaurant.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Okay, so they've been voted as having the best veggie burrito in the city.  I think it's GOOD, but I wouldn't say it's THE BEST. 

The veggie burritos are filled with delicousness, including slices of avocado.

I've had the veggie tacos a few times - if you're a strict vegetarian, be careful! I've found pieces of chicken burried in the tacos...
author: Sean G.

description:
This place is OK. Honestly, I don't see why Cancun has such a crazy rep. The food is standard taqueria fare, but its not mind blowing. If I'm having a Hamm's at the Knock Out I often pop in here to fill that salty void in my soul with a regular chicken burrito, but the truth is, its just OK. Pizza and Burrito joints near bars always tend to get better reviews because lets face, that shit is good when you are on a bender, but that skews the data.

La Altena down the street (by Safeway), while spotty at times, has fresher ingredients and a shorter line.
author: Zac H.

description:
A bit  disappointed with TC lately. Used to be my favorite for Carne Asada burritos, but something happened. The flavor is bland, something... perhaps the salsa lacks the punch it had. Perhaps it's just this location. Perhaps the location a little further down the Mission is better.

Their melon agua fresca is very good.

My search is still on for the San Diego style California Burrito;
Carne Asada, melted cheese and french fries... alas SD is a bit far to go for that.
author: Geordie E.

description: This place was awesome, I wish I could go every week! We were visiting from the UK and were recommended to go here by a friend who lives in SF. We had the veggie burrito and the super steak burrito, they were fantastic. Loved the avocado not guacamole, loved the amount of cheese, the price(!) and basically I'm very jealous of anyone who gets to go here regularly. Friendly and quick service too.
author: Cath A.

description: This burrito isn't quite as magical as El Farrolito, but it's pretty damn good.
author: Klevin D.

description:
A year ago, I probably would have given this place four, maybe five stars.  Can't put my finger on exactly why, but they've lost some zip on their fastball.

Maybe I'm just getting older.

Let's not forget this place still serves a solid burrito for $5.
author: Jackson R.

description:
Update: I do admit its the better spots to go to 'round hurr.

They must have somebody on the inside when those best of the bay articles come out. Because there are way too many places that rock burritos better then them. Stale chips and over greased quesadillas w/ cheese. Please.

The fellas that work there dont seem so happy either.
author: riz l.

description:
Upon moving from New York City, I realized that the Mexican food I was eating there was CRAP!

I'm addicted to these burritos. I can't get enough. The vegetarian super burrito is delicious. I love that they use fresh avocado instead of guacamole. They chips could be better (like not stale) but who can eat chips when you are eating a GIANT burrito!

Also, try the breakfast burrito. My friends and I have made it tradition.
author: Bella T.

description: I don't mean to give just "passing grades" to any/all of the taqueria's i've been to in the Mission but it's merely because I pretty much like them all and it can be hard to differentiate them.  I had a burrito here and it was competent and hit the spot; slightly more lime-flavored perhaps even.
author: Mike S.

description:
If you have not had there nachos - man you have no idea what living or eating for that matter is.  

I remember chowing nachos at the 7-11 in my yute...dang good right?  Or the nachos at Taco Bravo in Cupertino before they shut it down...now in Fremont ...

Ok back to these guys...the beef the cheese some kind of mad concoction- I cant explain it but they get all of it infused together perfectly so that you never are sitting there going - there is no cheese on this chip.

I usually will drop the car for a car wash on Van Ness and walk over...the walk back to the car is prolly a good idea- I thinks.

I have not had the burrito yet- although I am a creature of habit- I will try the burrito when someone else gets the nachos so that I can have both.

Avoid the lines go on a weekday lunch...or sit next to your fave drunk stranger on a weekend night.  The picnic tables make for nice socializing while you look across at the drunks scarfing down burritos.
author: Rob C.

description:
This local mini-chain serves the best veggie burrito in town.

Since this location is near me, the large breakfast plates are a godsend on Saturdays.

Another must-try is the ceviche tostadas, they used to be a buck twenty five but have gone up a bit in recent years.
author: Scott L.

description:
I do not understand what the hype around Cancun is.  If it weren't for people talking about it all the time I would never take particular note of it.  In my opinion there are many taquerias in San Francisco with better food.  As the guy before me mentioned, the chips are always stale, and they're from a bag.  They're not even freshly made.  

The place is nice and clean.  The employees are nice.  The prices are good.  But the food isn't remarkable at all.
author: Reid O.

description:
happy 100th review to you, happy 100th review to you, happy 100th review to youuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuu taqueria cancuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuun bernal heights location, happy 100th review to you.  LYLAS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

three words=super vegetable quesadilla.  ive never been able to order anything else because it's so insanely good.  full of avocado and spices mixed with a TON of cheese and sour cream fatty cooling goodness. let it drip all over your face and save it for later.
author: threeholepunch y.

description: When you're coming from El Rio, or from wherever your favorite watering hole is, Taqueria Cancun is the place to get grub. I have never been let down by their tacos or quesadillas.
author: Andy D.

description:
funny story. trekked out here to try the super burrito, since foodspotting's scavenger hunt for the 2010 100 things to try before you die (Big eat SF) had it on the map.... happened to just check the list to grab the # for said burrito, and the super burrito they list is for somewhere else. oops.

that said, good hearty food for like 6 bucks (CASH ONLY). big enough for me to split and keep for another meal, yay cheapness! spicer than expected (had pollo asado) and wayyyy more rice than expected.

random note: i asked for a whole wheat tortilla but my friend got it on his burriot instead. oh well.
author: S V.

description:
I can't believe all you crybabies whining about the atmosphere or the neighborhood. If you want Tony, stay in Pacific Heights where you belong. 

I can only imagine how much you whine about eateries in the Point or the Western Addition.

Folks, don't listen to the youthful morons with the sense of entitlement. This place ROCKS! Second only to Don Chuy's at Naples and Excelsior. The jukebox is GREAT, the chow is great, and if the young toughs keep the other kiddies away (it must be terrible to live in such fear of anyone  brown or black) that means there's more for the folks in the neighborhood. 

Get the Al Pastor burrito. Rocks the house. I hear they have carnitas so I'll have to try that, too.
author: Pete B.

description:
I've had a few veggie burritos at the Market st. location and always been satisfied - maybe it was the 2:30 am-ness of this outer mission franchise, but I was sorely dissapointed.  Yes cheap, yes big, but NO FLAVOR.  Also, I'm starting to think I need to skip on the cilantro when I get a burrito but thats just me.  Really though, this was just a sub-average burrito, and the guy was a jerk (just like the guy at the Market one - is that a requirement for Taqueria Cancun?)

My hunt for the best veggie burrito in the Mission continues.....At least this place has a working bathroom though.
author: Tmon B.

description:
Cancun is hands down, the best taco in the city. Get the super taco, with chicken or carne asada. the come fully loaded so you'll need to use the free chips to dip some toppings before picking up. with a cold Pacifico, or a mexican bottled coke, you can't go wrong. 

also, I'm lucky enough to live nextdoor!
author: Jevir G.

description: Have only had the (Mexican ceviche), but the deliciousness was consistent with their other locations...still wish they'd expand some more....
author: Mark A.

description: I ordered the veggie burrito and so far its the best veggie burrito I've had. Moderately spicy and a tasty sauce, not to mention that it was a gigantic burrito and I was full and happy. :)
author: Rahul P.

description:
So, I am an enormously avid burrito connoisseur, and this specific Taqueria Cancun location is by far the best I have encountered for just such a hobby. 

I've tried most of the menu, although I will say that my personal favorites are the veggie burrito (that being that I am in no way a vegetarian), and the super tacos  al pastor. 

I used to live two blocks away from this place and due to time and financial restraints could only eat once a day. This taqueria was not only perfectly substantial, but extremely affordable. ($4.88 for the aforementioned veggie burrito.) Also, the portions are so huge that I rarely finished anything in one sitting and could refrigerate and re-heat at my whim.

My only criticisms of this place are typical of good Mexican establishments: it's a little lacking in the hygene department and the guys who work there really love the ladies, if you know what I mean. I will say, however, that one rather cheery fellow with a mustache and thick-rimmed black glasses is really cordial. Two thumbs up!
author: Liz O.

description:
Just discovered another Taqueria today Sept 16th on Mexican Independence day. 

Just ordered a Chicken Super Burrito and my carnal ordered a Carne Asada Super Burrito. Pretty good

The menu looks promising

So far so good!

Update I have tasted the Torta and to be completely honest they are Horrible first they use a small currant bread bun (Torta buns are huge) and second they are not toasted as they should in the end they are soggy, so after eating here a second time the Burritos are still good but the Tortas suck A real Torta is huge well toasted and filling not small and soggy!!!!
author: Alberto L.

description: Absolutely the best burrito in the city that invented the modern burrito.  Pretty sure that makes it the best burrito in the world.
author: Tod G.

description: I generally like Taquerias, I'm a fan of cheap Mexican food that is open late. After six years in Phoenix, I developed quite an appreciation this concept. However, I found the meat to be much fattier than their competitors, Really wasn't super impressed with the chips, salsa or my carne asada. El Farlito is better and cheaper.
author: Marissa P.

description: Pretty good. Didn't have the "gurgles" afterwards. If ya kno what I mean.
author: Ressard S.

description: They have the best, THE BEST, al pastor tacos with extra salsa verde, the only thing that I ever want to eat after drinking at the Knockout.
author: Y K.

description: If I was standing outside it, it didn't have a line, and I was craving a burrito right then, I'd eat here (and this has happened multiple times - it's right by my apartment).  That makes this 1-star rating odd, because usually it means "avoid like the plague".  However, I can think of a solid half a dozen burrito places I like better nearby, and probably another half a dozen I haven't tried.  The Cancun at around 17th and Mission is dramatically better as well.  This place never has many people in it, which lets you get in and out faster, however means the ingredients just aren't as fresh, yet the staff doesn't seem to make as solid a product as other places.
author: Zachary R.

description:
YUMMIE! I've been coming here since it opened, and the Veggie Burrito is super yummie. So are the super nachos. And their green salsa is to die for. 

But alas, I can't bear to eat here anymore. Ever since the Health Dept gave them a 66 on their inspection card, I'm way too creeped out.
author: G G.

description: I stopped by here a few weeks ago after a brief bar hop from Elixir to 3300 Club to recharge and sober up.  I ordered the super taco with al pastor. Umm, umm, yummy. It was so good and quite a meal for about $3, and it comes with chips to boot. I highly recommend Taqueria Cancun al pastor super taco - do it, do it!
author: Frigga G.

description: Added to my list of late-night taquerias, Taqueria Cancun gives really good meat portions especially in their burritos. I find the spot a bit neater than others especially during late hours. The tacos and quesadillas are good, but I'm not a fan of their nachos grande, which require much more nachos, and their tortas are pretty small in size. Every now and then, I'll stop by early morning for one of their hearty breakfast plates- Huevos con Chorizo.
author: Leroid D.

description:
sober euge : well mannered, polite, patient
drunk euge : loud, loud, loud, 

sober euge : may come up with ideas to help fellow man
drunk euge : just might break a dol sot bi bim bap bowl over your head

sober euge : can i get an iced tea with that?
drunk euge : four grey goose chilled, in one cup

sober euge : meh taqueria cancun... meh. a big fat meh. 
drunk euge : THIS IS THE BEST FUCKING MESSICAN FOOD EVA  *drops pants*
author: Euge L.

description: I'd probably give it 2.5 stars really, but anyways, here's why: I've wanted to go to this place for a while now. As a vegetarian, I have a hard time shying away from anywhere that boasts it has "the best vegetarian burrito in san franciscio" and while out and about in the mission/bernal heights tonight, I was excited to finally try this place out. I wasn't all that hungry nor in a mood to spend money, so although I wanted to try the burrito, I settled for a cheese quesadilla with avocado instead (it came out to $4.07 - not a terrible price). They gave me some chips which were pretty average then, pretty quickly, my quesadilla came out. Up until this point I was a fan. But after I first bit into the quesadilla, I began noticing little bits of beef throughout (and trust me, it was definitely beef), hidden between the tortilla's layers. It probably wasn't intentional, but as a place that claims to have the best vegetarian burrito, I was sorely disappointed. There's a slight chance I might consider going back for the burrito, but after tonight's experience, I wouldn't be surprised if even that isn't truly vegetarian.
author: Roxy B.

description:
bomb chorizo con hueeeevos.....

bomb bean dip 

reasonable prices
author: Dessa R.

description: Easily the best Taqueria I've eaten at in San Francisco! I have to resist eating there most days. The food is delicious, cheap, and it is quick with take out. Favorites are the Super Nachos and Super burrito. Only potential downside is that it's packed at times and is cash only (not a surprise for most small San Fran restaurants). Highly recommended- midday or for a midnight snack.
author: Rachel G.

description:
To the haters:
maria & angela - don't eat the hot sauce if you don't enjoy sauces that are hot
don - super chicken quesadilla
catherine - s.c.q.
mr g - s.c.q.
steve s - no.
jonah - maybe you can't handle it?
will - s.c.q.
ejk - no.
kimberly - blue plate is the obvious culprit here.  oh and s.c.q.
jeremy - bring your own chips.  that and s.c.q.
scott - no.
chloe - "wasn't drunk! Well, I wasn't THAT drunk, anyway." yes you were.  also, s.c.q
vlad - 19th st. cancun is good only if you like to smell pee while you eat.  
gabriel - i can't help you if you cant taste.  (s.c.q.)
author: Jack S.

description: Blah! Don't confuse it with the other Taqueria further down Mission. This place's idea of vegetarian is just rice and beans with suspicious looking avocado. The colorful atmosphere reminded me of staying in a party after the clowns left.
author: Jasmine T.

description: this is my favorite place for al pastor!  i like how they use real avocado for the veggie burrito. the shrimp ceviche is a good alternative your normal taco or burrito.  busy late night spot.
author: Sheri N.

description: My feelings on Cancun are mixed. On the one hand, they use avocado instead of guac in their burritos, have grilled chicken instead of shredded chicken and grill their tortillas. On the other hand, their chips come from costco,  their salsa is so hot that it's almost unedible and they don't have carnitas, my number one favorite burrito stuffer.  In a pinch, it'll do.
author: Maria D.

description:
depite the advert one must unfortunately travel well north to taste fresh racoon meat, canned just isn't the same. ug. 
    wholewheat tortillas are good, and the workers genuinely smile and gather round to watch you take your first bite, then laugh uproarously and clap eachother on the back while asking in broken english "you...(gasp, laugh)like?!" I feel i've truly befriended these wily hooligans. Again, the foil takes some getting used to but the salsa and guac and convivial goodcheer more than make up for it.
author: owl c.

description:
blah blah blahbity blah... this place is just blah in comparison to the other Mission location. 

At this location I had the al pastor super quesadilla. It was good, but it was not great. 

At the other location I had the al pastor super burrito (thanks to Wakako. Hi Wakako!!) and that thing was mouth watering good. 

But having lunch with Eugy is always a pleasure. Thanks babe!

This place is CASH ONLY. But there is an ATM right next to the cash register.
author: Jen D.

description: Quite possibly the best burrito I have ever had. It had nothing to do with the fact that I had been drinking at El Rio for 3 hours, or that my friend went and got it so that I could keep drinking. No. It had to do with the perfectly marinaded meat, the spicy yummy salsa and the sour cream that was evenly spread throughout the whole burrito and the fact that I could not finish the whole thing and ended up giving it to the guy sitting next to me and making out with him for 20 minutes. Yes. The burrito was THAT good. I'd totally send someone out to pick another one up for me.
author: Brenda K.

description: First I have to admit I ate here after consuming a beer or two or three who knows. They may have gained an extra star because things taste and look better when you've been drinking. But I should add it was easy on the wallet.
author: Stacy F.

description: This is the best Burrito Al Pastor I have ever eaten.  I have gone back three times and I still love it.  You can taste the carmelized onions.  It is so rich and filling that I only need the regular size and I am totally filled and extremely happy.  And the cantelope agua fresca adds to a wonderful experience.
author: Nikki S.

description: My favorite of the three Taqueria Cancun locations in SF!  More spacious and less trafficked than the other locations.  A great place to enjoy a cheap and easy vegetarian burrito.  The aquacate salsa isn't fermenting here as it frequently is at the Mission St. location.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
few salsas rival cancun's. they both have kick and they're not runny. f'n awesome. i used to live a block away and ate here much more than i'd care to admit. but c'mon, a MEAL for $4.... are you kidding me?! god i love the mission. 

i did usually get veggie options there. if i did get a meat, it was steak. they use both white and dark meat chicken (mostly dark) and i loathe dark meat so that's the only drag about the place. but the veggie burrito is just so damn good that i didn't even miss having chicken.

the horchata is good, especially when it's fresh. and i can't say enough about the salsas.
author: Sidney B.

description: I always order a grilled chicken burrito because you can never go wrong. No sour cream and with black beans. This location is better then the one on Market street because it is kinda scary down there with all of those hobos. The burrito came with free chips and a lot of salsa which I like!  or which I LOVE!! But the burrito came with very little chicken which kinda sucks because in other places they LOAD of the chicken!!! I was kind of disappointed. They have a lot of awards on their wall! Yeah this place do look very clean!! I would come here again if I would venture here.
author: Janet Z.

description:
I felt as though a little piece of me died last night as I ate my burrito
Under the fluorescent lighting that cast a yellow aura to the
 already yellow on yellow dining room
My husband kept picking crunchy, tough pieces of chicken out of his mouth (he had the chicken tortas)
And the "chips" were clearly from a giant bag purchased from Costco

Cancun was my very first west coast burrito experience  
 (although for the life of me I don't remember which location it was...oopsie)
this was more than a decade ago...
 And I was forever changed
The burritos I ate during that summer in San Francisco were a large part of the reason I fell in love with the Bay Area
I have spoken so fondly of these burritos over the years
And that memory of the perfect burrito has always held an important place in my heart
 So now I am older, and worldlier in the ways of the burrito
I did notice the last time I ate here (maybe 6 months ago)
That it didn't do it for me
I quickly made excuses... I thought perhaps it was just that I was eating at 2:30 AM after way too many cocktails next door at the knockout
and quickly pushed the experience from my mind
recently upon learning  I would be going to a show at the Knockout 
I was excited at the thought of going to Cancun
I was ready to rekindle the romance from my early 20's
 However nothing tasted right
 The rice was dull... the beans flavorless, 
  the cheese and sour cream overwhelmed each bite (not in a complimentary way)
 and while the avocado was very visible- the taste of it was nowhere to be found
 I think it's over between us now
But I will never forget that day I fell in love
author: Maxine M.

description:
not likely to ever come here again.  since there are closer / better burrito places near where i live.

there is a Cancun on 18th and mission too, had a good wet burrito there once. As well as el faralito on 24th and mission had a really good carne asada quesadilla suiza the other night (then I went home and threw up but i dont think it was cause of the quesadilla)

The health inspection score (green card) for this particular cancun shows a score of 66. SIXTY SIX!

is this even legal?  shouldnt this place be condemned?
Chaya on 18th and Valencia has a score of 88 and already that sounds low.  Burger Joint has a score of 95, but that place looks antiseptic almost.  I dont even know what the score represents, just that the higher the better.  So i imagine the score is made up something like this : start with 100 points subtract 1 point each for the # of boogers and rat poop found in or around the food prep area.  That's alot of boogers.

you know what? i hate burritos.   why do i live in the mission?  fock me.

** copied and pasted review  originally posted in the 18th/mission page
author: Irvin S.

description: Their $4 vegetarian burritos saved me from going insane from drunken hunger. Who knows, I was so wasted that I may have started to eat the napkins I keep in my purse had it not been for their burritos.
author: Courtney S.

description: Just don't get the hype. Yes it's cheap & it fills you up but so do Ramen noodle. Oh and I have had many a vegetarian friend get a littl meat surprise in their burrito.
author: Catherine D.

description: Another taqueria with good food. I'd say the winner of the block is El Zocalo (despite it being a Salvadorean restaurant instead), but if you want quick food, Taqueria Cancun is the place to go. I like how they use fresh avocados in the dishes vs guacamole, but that's personal preference. Way too much competition in the area for me to come here again anytime soon. It was good, but it wasn't enough to make this a favorite.
author: Jonas T.

description: Best taco in the mission!  The burrito, enchiladas, and other dishes are average for San Francisco.  On the plus side its open late.
author: BeeryMcGymrat X.

description: The only reason this place gets high marks is because it's open late and it's cheap..the quality of the ingredients are so-so...the salsa is hot (bfd) it doesn't take cooking know how to add more chile into the salsa..and they don't have carnitas....anyway, there's a lot of taquerias out there that are way better.
author: Brenda D.

description: I appreciate the fact that they grill the burritos here.  Last time I ordered horchata it was pretty sweet with no ice, so I had to water it down a bit, but otherwise it's all you could ask for in a taqueria.
author: Rick B.

description:
you know, we went to this place one for lunch instead of el farolito, and it was ok.  

but i don't think i'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Steve S.

description:
Besides the fact that I always feel just a little sick after eating  here, it has to be one of my favorite taquerias. When my husband and I used to live south of Market we would frequent the Market location, but we would never actually eat there. I much prefer the bernal heights/mission location. There isn't that fear of a crack addict coughing on your food while you go  to enjoy your first bite or the fear of wearing open toed shoes because of the used needle littered streets just around the corner on 6th street. This is a much calmer environment. I enjoy the whole chunks of avocado in the burritos and the flavors  are just right. 
   The last time I was there the taco jockey went hefty on the cheese and the meat. How can anyone not dig those perks? ( apologies to the vegans of the world, you suffer enough without it being rubbed it your face) On the subject of meat I do find it a bit disappointing that they do not have carnitas. That's like a cat without fur, sure it is still a cat but who wants to cuddle it? It's missing something. The chips are also my other complaint. Invest in a fryer, that's all I have to say. 
     On a good note though, they make tasty horchata and salsa, and the tortas are pretty kick awesome as my brother would say. Overall the people are always friendly, the food is  always tasty, and the price is right!
author: Esa Y.

description: Once again, good but no La Corneta. Open super late, good salsa bar.
author: Catherine K.

description: This is our local taqueria, within walking distance and all that.  We probably eat here approximately twice a week.  Personally, my very favorite place for carne asada burritos remains La Taqueria.  But that's a 15 minute walk and this is 5 minutes.  And aside from LT's carne asada burrito, this Mission St. location of Taqueria Cancun gets my vote for everything else.  The al pastor burrito or quesadilla is to die for, and I usually do as I end up overeating.  The sauce is just delicious.  My son could literally eat their bean/cheese/avocado burrito three times a day if we would let him.  Hidden gem on the menu - the tostada de ceviche.  Super cheap and tasty.  Close your eyes and you would swear you were at Maya paying like five times as much.
author: Valerie W.

description: I like this location a lot more than the other one on Mission. Similar setup and options, but a lot less crowded. Only negative is that it constantly smells like bleach in here. Not very appetizing.
author: Rocky K.

description: My favorite taqueria in SF!  Good cheap veggie burritos with chunks of fresh avocado are a staple for neighbors on a budget.  My favorite is the Al Pastor.  Best marinated pork around!  The Horchata rules, and the agua de melon is awsome as well.  You can also order a fresh carrot orange juice if your into that kind of thing.
author: Josiah B.

description: Not as good as the Cancun at 19th and Mission.  That's really all you need to know.  Not enough cilantro, not enough avocado, the tortilla wasn't grilled the way it's supposed to be, you're not sitting on those awesome long wooden benches... Just go down the street to the other location and eat the best burrito of your life!
author: Anna W.

description:
the place san jose will just never compare to........

the food is absolutely great. and it's fast. and it's cheap. and they give you good chips and salsa while you wait. and they have Mexican music blasting in the background. and they have cool Mexican deco hanging from the ceiling. and they have beer.

they also carry the ever popular super burrito, which has come to be an integral part of whether or not i like a burrito joint. i think this is the best burrito place in the mission hands down.
author: David D.

description: My go-to spot for a quick and easy veggie burrito (with everything). Cheap, reliable, fast, open late. Not as good as Papalote.
author: Dan M.

description: If there was Nobel prize in the category of chirizo burritos, Taqueria Cancun would win easily. This is the best burrito EVAR. The only thing that comes close is the El Faralito carne asada burrito. Luckily, being comprised of beef puts it out of the running for the chirizo burrito Nobel prize, so we won't have to make that tough call.
author: Gabe M.

description: Best burrito I've had in ages.  And I eat my fair share.  One complaint would be how stingy they are with the salsa.  Their green salsa is very good, but they only give you one ramekin.  There is no salsa bar.  Chips are not homemade, either.
author: Nathan W.

description: Really good, unique Al Pastor. Everything else is average. Cheap.
author: Don H.

description:
You know what? 5! Well, rounded up from 4.5 because of the obnoxious conversation you sort of listen in or out for in that particular neighborhood. If obsessive hairstylings and bulged pants are what your parents thought were cool, who knows, in the evening this place could be bothersome. If you couldn't care any less about atmosphere or ambiance, like myself for the most part, then go. And it is open nice and late for those of you with sleeping or partying disorders and orders. 

The Veggie Burrito is number one in the hood for a reason. Get it and you'll enjoy it, or I'll buy it. I live up the street and if you time your email right, I'll pick up the tab, my man. Certain stipulations may apply, offer ends pretty soon. 

I wish I knew a secret menu for this place. Do you know what I mean? - Freshly squeezed juice upon request, in any case.
author: Turkey N.

description: Be forewarned: the salsa is hot, and anything you order with salsa in it will be hot.  You can request for them to leave out the hotness, though.  I was spared because I ordered the basic quesadilla (carne asada and cheese).  We were going to a house party in the neighborhood and we needed a bite - this turned out to be a good pick.
author: Angela W.

description: Completely dissastisfying...even when starving.  My friend almost started crying, her burrito was so awful. But maybe it's because we really wanted to go to Blue Plate, and waited an hour until 6 when it was posted to open, but eventually called to find out they aren't open on Sundays...
author: Kimberly K.

description: Solid taqueria with fantastic food. Burrito was fresh and tasty and portions are huge. Truly a good value for the money. The only reason I didn't give it a full 5 stars is because I still have a bit of San Diegan snobbery left in me in terms of authentic and excellent Mexican food. However, for the San Francisco bay area, the food here really almost did remind me of home.
author: Stephen C.

description: Cancun, I don't know what happened to you?????  I go away to Africa to do humanitarian work at a hospital and on the flight back all I could think about was eating one of your delicious awesome burritos.  I used to eat your fantastic food 3-4 times a week.....but now I don't know if I want to go back.  What a big frowny face :-(  Your beans tasted burnt, the meat was very dried out, and the rice.....um just no.  This is coming from someone who has been on rationed crappy food Cancun.    But! The guys behind the counter recognized me, asked where I have been and were very polite as always.  So that is why you don't get the 1 star.  I will be back to try again and hope this was just one of those off cooking days.  Because everyone and everything deserves 2nd chances right??  I think so!!
author: Suzanne C.

description: Decent burritos and the price is right.  The chips and salsa come free too!  The staff is always very friendly as well
author: Sarah K.

description: Some drunk girl at El Rio said these were the best burritos in the city, though she admitted that's a subjective question.  She must prize blandness above all other qualities when it comes to rating burritos.  Further, she must either be a vegetarian or love low-grade meat.  This place is okay, but it's not very good.
author: Jes H.

description: The carnitas quesadilla was pretty good! The only problem was we ordered three suiza and instead they gave us the smaller ones. Next time I'd send them back, however at 2am its kind of hard to be picky...
author: Nicolas H.

description: The quesadilla suiza seems better suited for 2am than breakfast.
author: David R.

description: Two stars, giving them the benefit of the doubt, that the guy at the counter was too spaced out, or he was just a jerk at midnight.  The meat here has got a lot of carcass and junk, and the veggie burrito without cheese/dairy, comes with sour cream and chesse, I mean was he "f-ing" with me?  Anyways, if I'm hungry enough, sure I'll eat here after the Knockout or El Rio, but Farolito, Castillo, or the Cancun on 19th/Mission are better, if you're still kinda sober and have taste buds.
author: EJ K.

description:
Great pitstop to El Rio the bar on Mission and Precita.  

(2 stars off for the chips. They are the yellow corn store bought. ) 

(1 star off for the "el crepador" effect. Sketchy and skivy)
author: Juhi D.

description: The southern-most, being the cleanest, is my favorite, though the one at 19th has the best atmosphere. The food is good at all of them, but everything tastes worse on 6th St. LOVE the pollo asado burrito, and the green salsa too. Tasty breakfasts also. Cheap!
author: Jonny A.

description:
Was walking on Mission and trying to decide what to eat for dinner.
